item.title: Chronic Limb Ischaemia
item.description: A 72 year old man is referred to the vascular outpatient department. He has a background of hypertension, hyperlipidaemia, and type 2 diabetes mellitus. He reports pain in his right calf when mobilising over 200m over the last 6 months. This pain is relieved by rest. He reports no rest pain and no ulcers. Question 2 What are the risk factors for chronic limb ischaemia? .quiz fieldset { border-color: black; border-width: 5px; margin-bottom: 1em; } .

item.title: Chronic Limb Ischaemia
item.description: Background Chronic limb ischaemia is a symptomatic reduced arterial blood supply to the limbs Causes Primary: vasculitis Secondary: atherosclerosis; radiation; trauma; inflammation secondary to infection; rare causes such as popliteal artery entrapment Risk Factors Non modifiable: age; family history Modifiable: smoking; T2DM; hypertension; obesity; hyperlipidaemia Presentation Presentation depends on the severity of disease Individuals may present with claudication, a muscular, cramp like pain when walking, which is relieved by rest.

item.title: Diabetic Foot
item.description: Question 7 The gentleman is admitted for intravenous antibiotics. The ulcer grows in size and is associated with increasing erythema. The patient becomes febrile and tachycardic. He is taken to theatre for debridement and deep tissue/bone sample. Bone sample confirms osteomyelitis and he is commenced on flucloxacillin, as per sensitivities. What is the minimum antibiotic course for an individual with confirmed osteomyelitis? .quiz fieldset { border-color: black; border-width: 5px; margin-bottom: 1em; } .

item.title: Diabetic Foot
item.description: Summary Background Diabetic foot disease includes: infection; ulceration and tissue loss Diabetic foot disease affects just under 6% of people with diabetes Foot ulceration increases an individuals risk of infection and amputation Complications can be prevented with good foot care and screening These patients require a multi disciplinary team to provide comprehensive care to prevent these complication Causes Types of diabetic foot ulcers include: Neuropathic â€“ secondary to peripheral neuropathy Ischaemic â€“ secondary to peripheral arterial disease Mixed â€“ a combination of neuropathic and ischaemic Peripheral arterial disease Diabetes causes damages to blood vessels by inflammation and atherosclerosis.

item.title: Examination
item.description: Lower limb arterial examination Inspection Colour (mottling, pallor, necrosis) Ulcers (located at pressure points, small, well defined, punched out edges, deep and painful) â€“ describe site, size, shape, base, surrounding skin. Trophic changes (hair loss, shiny skin) Scars Previous amputation Gangrene Palpation Temperature Capillary refill time Pulses (radial â€“ brachial â€“ carotid â€“ aorta â€“ femoral â€“ popliteal â€“ dorsalis pedis â€“ posterior tibial) Gross sensation Special tests Bergerâ€™s With the patient lying flat on the bed, elevate the straight legs until the toes become pale.

item.title: Vascular history
item.description: Summary Presenting complaint Pain: SOCRATES Aneurysm: Usually asymptomatic but patients may report abdominal or back pain Peripheral arterial disease: A cramping type pain in the buttock or calf which occurs with exertion, usually at a consistent distance. The pain is relieved by rest. Ask how far the patient can walk before they have pain/need to stop (claudication distance). In critical limb ischaemia, individuals describe rest pain or night pain, which is relieved by hanging the foot over the edge of the bed.
